name: q17_7
probTex: Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a locally bounded family of holomorphic functions on a region $\Omega$. Prove (without invoking Montel's theorem) that $\mathcal{F}$ is equicontinuous at every point of $\Omega$.
solnTex:
Suppose that $\mathcal{F}$ is locally bounded at all points in $\Omega$. Take the constants $M,r$ from the definition of locally bounded, also choose $r$ small enough so that $\overline{B_r(z_0)}\subset\Omega$. That is, for all $z\in B_r(z_0)$ and all $f\in\mathcal{F}$, we have asusmed that $|f(z)|\leq M$.
Let $\epsilon>0$ be given. Let $z\in\Omega$ with $|z-z_0|< rac{r}{2}$. Let $\gamma$ be the circle $|z-z_0|=r$. By Cauchy's integral formula applied to arbitrary $f\in\mathcal{F}$, 
\[|f(z)-f(z_0)|=\left| rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma rac{f(w)}{w-z}dw- rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma rac{f(w)}{w-z_0}dwight|= rac{1}{2\pi}\left|\int_\gamma rac{f(w)(z-z_0)}{(w-z)(w-z_0)}dwight|\]
\[\leq rac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\left| rac{f(w)(z-z_0)}{(w-z)(w-z_0)}ight||dw|.\]
Here we will use some bounds. $|f(w)|\leq M$, $|w-z_0|=r$, and $|w-z|\geq rac{r}{2}$. Thus
\[ rac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\left|f(w)(z-z_0) rac{1}{w-z} rac{1}{w-z_0}ight||dw|\leq rac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma M|z-z_0| rac{2}{r} rac{1}{r}|dw|= rac{M}{\pi r^2}|z-z_0|\int_\gamma|dw|= rac{2M}{r}|z-z_0|.\]
Therefore if we choose $\delta$ to be $0<\delta< rac{r}{2}$ (so this whole argument applies) and less than $ rac{r\epsilon}{2M}$, then we have shown that $\mathcal{F}$ is equicontinuous because
\[|f(z)-f(z_0)|\leq rac{2M}{r}\delta< rac{2M}{r} rac{r\epsilon}{2M}=\epsilon.\]
